city_conflict.description: Shuso Corrections feels the fees it pays to Lurpeko Minerals for mining shares are exorbitant.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: The fact that both are subsidiaries of Vorsiber doesn't matter to either of them. Both sides value their own little kingdoms.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Shuso got their way. Lurpeko is very unhappy.

defender_victory_outcome.description: Lurpeko prevailed. The status quo is maintained.
Lurpeko prevailed, and even managed to further increase the fees. Shuso is livid.

city_conflict.description: Bitter from their inability to force Lurpeko Minerals to reduce fees on mining shares, Shuso Corrections has enlisted Falsom Detention to try to force the issue.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: These two prison companies spend most of their time squabbling in their sector, so having them work together is rather unusual.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Both prison companies had their fees reduced. Lurpeko is very unhappy.

defender_victory_outcome.description: Lurpeko prevailed, despite the odds. The status quo is maintained.

city_conflict.description: Lurpeko Minerals, furious at being bested by a lowly prison company, has hired a PMC to help them renegotiate their fees.
Espia Telecom wants direct control of some of the City Feed repeater towers on property belonging to Tark, Goleri, and Atca.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: The normal agreement is for a lease from the telecom company. Why does Espia care about this all of a sudden?

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Espia has acquired more control of the city feed.

city_conflict.description: Prison labor is instrumental for the manufacture of certain kinds of small munitions. Tark is offended that the prison companies have fallen below quota.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: Exactly what they hope to accomplish here is unclear. It probably makes sense to someone in an executive suite.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: At least, they think they did. Prisoner output is unchanged...

defender_victory_outcome.description: The prison companies are very proud that they've defended the productivity merits of those they have incarcerated.

city_conflict.description: Offended that not only is prison labor output still the same, but that they lost the last conflict on the subject Tark is investing far more heavily into another round of fighting.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: A sensible corporation would enlist the help of a PMC or another federated corporation, but Tark is just shipping more of their own soldiers into the city.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: At least, they think they did. Prisoner output is unchanged...

defender_victory_outcome.description: The prison companies are very proud that they've defended the productivity merits of those they have incarcerated.

city_conflict.description: Goleri Expeditionary wants a share of two rival corporations' districts. Everything is ultimately owned by the Megacorp, but corporation control is a matter of pride.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: District lines haven't been redrawn in over 200 years, but that doesn't stop corporations from trying.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Vorsiber stepped in and blocked Goleri, despite Goleri prevailing. No wonder the district lines never change.

defender_victory_outcome.description: The two weaker corporations managed to fend off Goleri.

city_conflict.description: Asi Solutions has tried leveraging control of the executive food supply to gain access to military holdings. It has been unsuccessful. The next resort is violence.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: It seems they are tired of being thought of as a soft target.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Against all odds, Asi Solutions prevailed. Vorsiber was unmoved, so they get nothing.

defender_victory_outcome.description: The trio of military corporations are pleased to have put this upstart in its place.

city_conflict.description: Oerl Integrated is running a broad campaign of revenge attacks on the agricultural corporations as payback for a prior betrayal.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: The nature of the betrayal is apparently a closely-guarded secret.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Onlookers remain baffled as to what happened.

defender_victory_outcome.description: They refuse to drop the issue, whatever it is.

city_conflict.description: Oerl is back after their prior defeat, this time enlisting the aid of two PMCs to help fight.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Onlookers remain baffled as to what happened.

defender_victory_outcome.description: They're dropping the issue... for now.

city_conflict.description: The agricultural corporations, furious at the beating they previously took from Oerl, have hired two PMCs to fight on their behalf.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: It's somewhat unusual, and seen as a bit cowardly, for corporations engaged in open conflicts to not send in their own troops alongside the PMCs they've hired. They must be having a bad quarter.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Onlookers remain baffled as to what happened.

defender_victory_outcome.description: They're dropping the issue... for now.

city_conflict.description: Atca is livid that they are unable to compete with Nath Vertical on pricing in several sectors. They're attacking their main supplier to try to lower prices.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Onlookers are shocked that actually worked.

defender_victory_outcome.description: Atca was unable to prevail even with PMC assistance.

city_conflict.description: Lurpeko Minerals wants to open more mines. They're attacking four other federated corporations in an effort to get surveyors' rights in districts they control.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Vorsiber denied the permit, despite Lurpeko prevailing in combat. They tightly control the rate of mineral depletion in this region.

city_conflict.description: Graff believes that Dyad has been selling them faulty tools in order pull ahead of them in industrial sectors where they directly compete.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: Both sides have pulled in PMCs to help.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: It was pretty blatant. Vorsiber has ordered Dyad to provide proper quality tools.

defender_victory_outcome.description: Graff was unable to prevail against Dyad, and it would be too expensive for them to try again right now.

city_conflict.description: Baurcorp is furious at what it sees as slander happening on the City Feed. The offending material is hosted in Arkor data centers, and Arkor has refused to take it down.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: Arkor Nexus tends to enjoy hosting controversial commentary, so long as it doesn't involve themselves or Vorsiber.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Arkor is unhappy, but has taken the offending material down.

city_conflict.description: Nath Vertical believes that Vericorp detonated a micro-nuke on some of their holdings.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: The reality is that middle-managers at Baurcorp assembled a 'ghost nuke,' which even their bosses don't know about. And you were the one who detonated it.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: From Nath's perspective, the offense has been paid in blood.

defender_victory_outcome.description: From Vericorp's perspective, they have defended their honor.

city_conflict.description: Lawyers for a hardliner sect of the Solarism religion are entangled with legal requests to Vorsiber itself. They want to know why space launches have been shut down, and if that can be extended indefinitely.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: They've been arguing for the shutdown of the spaceport ever since it was built, centuries ago. This sect must be quite happy at the moment, but still they can't help but engage in legal challenges.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: The Solarists won their legal challenge, but Vorsiber unilaterally overruled them anyway. That can happen. The law is whatever Vorsiber says.

defender_victory_outcome.description: The Solarists were not able to fully execute their legal challenge.

city_conflict.description: Baurcorp is alleging that Tark is using civilian ground vehicles to re-distribute their troops in a bid to foster illegal excess loyalty in the infantry under their control.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: Tark vehemently denies this, as this is an incredibly serious accusation. They assert that they are simply allowing infantry to use civilian vehicles when on leave, to visit friends at other bases.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Baurcorp prevailed. Tark has been fined heavily, and extra inspectors are being added. A hundred vice presidents have been sent to prison.

defender_victory_outcome.description: Vorsiber found Baurcorp's evidence to be lacking.

city_conflict.description: Peak Homes is suing on behalf of a collective of their wealthiest clients. They claim that an unlawful fraction of the local agricultural output is being 'lost' to the black markets.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: This lost output tends to find its way to the lower classes, which their clients find frankly insulting.

aggressor_victory_outcome.description: Vorsiber has allocated extra inspectors to be sure that the agricultural corporations keep to the law. There will be less fresh produce available for the lower classes.

defender_victory_outcome.description: Asi and Yinshi have successfully argued that they are within tolerances, and that their first duty is to profits.

city_conflict.description: Gang activity is constant and low-intensity. But if you stir them up, it's likely to get much more violent.
city_conflict.strategy_tip: Most gangs don't last very long if they lose a conflict like this, so the smart ones stay out of it.
